attributes.comment:
The fees increases proposed here are fair and will properly be used to fund better
service for those that are filing for benefits. However, I do not believe that these fees
are being applied to enough programs.

The H-1B non-immigrant visa for example, has a very low application fee, which
encourages bodyshops and outsourcing companies to file for thousands of H-1B
positions. These large applications then cause the visa allocations to be completely
used within hours of the annual opening, which in turn causes American companies to
complain that more job-stealing visas are necessary in order for them to hire
specialized workers.

If the H-1B application fee were set to 10% or 15% of the proposed annual salary
($5,000 to $7,5000), then fewer companies would file for thousands of H-1bs, and the
visa allocations would not be used for run-of-the-mill bodyshopping.

This one increase alone would be enough to support USCIS, and to provide for
additional funds for enforcement. The only people that would complain would be those
bodyshoppers that are currently able to import thousands of low-paid, underpaid
indentured servants.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Walter R. Crosby
